awd_titl_txt: I-Corps: Functionalized metal oxide nano-particles for printable solar cells
awd_abstract_narration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this I-Corps project is the advancement of perovskite solar cell technology, making it more accessible and affordable for a wider range of applications. The project's innovative functionalized inks address key challenges in perovskite solar cell manufacturing, including cost reduction and compatibility with various layers in the solar cell stack. By offering a cost-effective, high-quality solution for solar cell manufacturers, the project can promote the adoption of renewable energy technologies, ultimately leading to reduced greenhouse gas emissions and decreased reliance on fossil fuels. The commercial impact of this project extends to startups and established companies within the perovskite solar cell industry, as it enables them to produce solar modules at a lower cost, creating a more competitive market and driving innovation.

This I-Corps project is based on the development of functionalized metal-oxide charge transport layers for solar cells, which offer a significant reduction in layer costs and facilitate solution-phase processing. The project's core innovation is the functionalization of nanoparticles with acetate ligands, allowing for dispersion in perovskite-compatible anhydrous ethanol and providing unmatched process flexibility. This innovative approach overcomes the challenges of solvent incompatibility and processing temperature constraints that have limited the choice of materials for charge transport layers. The resulting dispersion is not only cost-effective, but also compatible with low-temperature processing techniques, making it an ideal solution for flexible solar applications. The project also explores the potential of functionalized nitrogen oxide as an alternative, offering similar advantages in cost, stability, and manufacturability.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Introduction Through the NSF I-Corps program, Sofab Inks explored the commercial potential of our novel tin-oxide nanoparticle inks for perovskite solar cell manufacturing. Our goal was to assess market viability, identify key customer needs, and refine our value proposition. This experience provided invaluable insights into the intersection of cutting-edge materials science and real-world industry applications.

Intellectual Merit Sofab Inks developed the world’s first tin-oxide nanoparticle ink that can be directly deposited onto perovskite solar cells, addressing critical challenges in next-generation solar manufacturing. Traditional materials, such as fullerenes, suffer from high costs and scalability issues, limiting the commercial adoption of perovskite technology. By leveraging our proprietary ink formulation, we demonstrated a more cost-effective, durable, and scalable solution that enhances device longevity and efficiency. The NSF I-Corps program allowed us to validate this technological advantage through extensive customer discovery. 

Broader Impacts The potential impact of Sofab Inks’ technology extends beyond just improving perovskite solar cells. Our work contributes to the broader adoption of renewable energy by enabling more affordable and longer-lasting solar panels, thus reducing reliance on fossil fuels. Additionally, by fostering collaborations with manufacturers and research institutions worldwide, we are helping to accelerate the commercialization of sustainable energy solutions. The program also allowed us to refine our messaging and understand how our technology fits within global supply chains. 

Key Outcomes Throughout the NSF I-Corps program, we conducted over 100 customer interviews with solar cell manufacturers, research labs, and supply chain partners. These interviews helped us refine our product-market fit and identify key industry pain points, including:

  • The demand for more stable and scalable materials in perovskite solar cells.
  • The need for a cost-effective alternative to fullerenes without sacrificing efficiency.
  • The importance of supply chain reliability and regulatory compliance for large-scale adoption.

As a direct result of our participation in the program, we successfully built a pipeline of over 30 interested customers, secured letters of support from major industry players, and positioned Sofab Inks as a leader in perovskite material innovation. Furthermore, we refined our go-to-market strategy, focusing on early adopters in research and development before scaling to commercial production.

Conclusion The NSF I-Corps program was instrumental in transforming our scientific research into a viable business opportunity. By engaging directly with industry stakeholders, we gained critical market insights that shaped our business strategy and product development. Moving forward, Sofab Inks Inc. is well-positioned to drive innovation in perovskite solar technology, contributing to the global transition to sustainable energy solutions.

 


Last Modified: 02/07/2025
Modified by: Thad L Druffel
